content.description: For those lacking a large rack of cams or those who are new to the Creek; this is a great place to start.  Also, there is a really cool cave to the right of this route where you can actually walk back in the rock behind this climb.  Bring you headlamp.
content.location:
Located between Friction Slab and Blue Gramma. Look for a small pull off east of the road. The route climbs the splitter up white-ish rock to the easily visible slings.

GPS: 38.022576 (lat), -109.539510 (lon)

content.description:
I love this route! You must pass this route before you enter the creek (AKA Entrance Exam).

Starts in an offwidth-y wedge and pulls a roof with bouldery moves and fingerlocks. Then climb the zig-zagging crack with hands and big hands. It gets steep and pumpy towards the top.
content.protection: 0.3-3, mostly 2 and 3 (a #6 is helpful to protect the last bit of the wedge before getting gear in the roof)
content.location: 1.7 miles from Newspaper Rock on the right side

content.description: P1)Starts at a crack on the east side. Up this to the gap and belay .60'5.8 P2)Move out onto the south side and some bolts lead up a slab to the summit. 50'
content.location: This semi hidden tower (but visible from the road) is not on the Friction slab ,but this maybe the closest crag , The tower is on the other side of the road up a small canyon with a pull off on the left side of the road . The pull off at the head of the canyon is 1.8 miles passed Newspaper rock when driving into the creek. It takes only a few mins to walk to the tower from the road.

climbs.name: Sundance
climbs.fa: Ed Webster, Patrick Griffin, and Udom Likhitwonnawut. May 1984

content.description: Sandstone slab with two bolts on route to an I-bolt anchor.  The crux is after the first bolt.  A nice climb for those in your party not into the typical offerings of Indian Creek or those who's hands need some rest.
content.protection: Coupla draws for the two bolts and something for the anchor.
content.location: Left most route on the Friction Slab.

content.description:
A good introduction to

Indian Creek

,

Split Pinnacle

tackles a tight hands to fist crack up the center of a short leaning tower. Disappointing in length, its still a nice and quick stop if you're looking to get a feel for hand cracks.

Easily accessible from the road, This is a fun route to do if you're short on time, just arriving, or looking for a mellow warm-up or warm-down.

Start by diving right in on the thinnest part of the crack. Squirm your way up the generous start until you can start burying those hands with solid jams. Keep climbing til the hands turn to fists, give a grunt and pop out on top at a chain anchor.
content.protection: Cams from 3/4" to 4" (.75-#3 bd or equivalent). Chain anchor.
content.location:
Located about 0.6 miles past

Newspaper Rock

and on the right just after the

Friction Slabs

is

Split Pinnacle

. Parking can be found just prior too and on the left by the campground. Walk down the road until the crack becomes visible. Its the only obvious splitter set about 15 off the road.

content.description:
Pitch 1: 13b/c fingers recently first free ascent (3/10/21) by Charlie Barrett

Pitch 2: 5.9 hands and wide hands

Pitch 3: fist and/or O.W. roof. Grade ranges from hand size. Pat says 5.12 OW
content.location: On the right 1.5 miles past newspaper rock.

content.description: Face and slab climbing up thin holds past 4 fixed pitons.  The top is at the break and there is a three bolt anchor.
content.location: The start is just to the left of a juniper.

content.description: Climb the sweet orange corner by jamming and stemming up past a cool manganese band, with several nice ledges to place from. Crux comes near the top with some thin flaring fingers with  a bit of pack rat poop in the back. Be careful of loose rock as the route will  clean up nicely with some traffic.
content.protection: Thin fingers through fist sized pieces to a bolted anchor with rap rings.
content.location: This route is (perhaps) the last route you see as you are leaving the creek on the left hand side of the road before switch-backing out. I believe this outcrop is actually Navajo sandstone. Park off the road and a quick tip toe on some animal trails will keep you off of the crypto on your way to the base.

content.description: Inside corner formed by a legal-to-climb arch. Starts as an easy offwidth for 15' with some loose chockstones in the bottom for feet, becoming progressively smaller as you move up. Somewhat sandy.
content.protection:
Take a 4.5 or 5 camalot if you want pro for the wide lower section.

Double set of hand down to finger size for the rest

Two pins w/ tat and a shiny bolt for anchors.
content.location: Route is about a 3 to 5 minute walk up the road to the right of Split Pinnacle, around mile marker 5.9.
